title: Roland Wright, pilot of the 'Mormon Mustang,' dies at 96
text: Roland Wright, pilot of the ‘Mormon Mustang,’ dies at 96 By NATE CARLISLE | The Salt Lake Tribune First Published 1 hour ago • Updated 2 minutes ago Courtesy of Utah National Guard Gen. Roland R. Wright Courtesy of Utah National Guard Gen. Roland R. Wright Share This Article ARTICLE PHOTO GALLERY (10) Roland Wright, the World War II and Korean War fighter pilot who flew the "Mormon Mustang," died Monday. He was 96. Wright's death was announced in a paid obituary published Friday. A cause of death was not listed. Wright made his name over Europe in World War II. The P-51 mustang he flew became known as the "Mormon Mustang." Wright shot down three enemy aircraft during the war. After World War II, Wright became one of the first airmen to join the fledgling Utah Air National Guard. With it, Wright was called to duty to fly a fighter jet during the Korean War and an air-refueling tanker during the Vietnam War. VIDEOS Check out all the Trib TopJobs He retired from the Utah Åir National Guard in 1976 with the rank of brigadier general. Last year, the National Guard base adjacent to Salt Lake City International Airport was renamed the Roland R. Wright Utah Air National Guard Base. Wright was on hand at a ceremony as a parachute was pulled away to reveal the new sign at the base's entrance. The Tribune will update this story as more information is available.
